content.description:
About twenty feet left of arete is nice, tight crack. Climb it to a double bolt anchor on

Man's Best Friend

.

Rap that route.
content.location: After crossing a bridge, head upstream for 200 feet head toward a clearing below an open area under a face. The crack is little but not very dirty. There are a couple plants in the crack.

content.description:
The next right-facing dihedral to the left of

Coronabushes

provides interesting movement up strange features that resemble tufas. The features are more solid than those appear to be. The lower half of the pitch is dirty and would be hard to protect. The upper half is the same as that of

Coronabushes

.
content.protection: Toprope from the Unknowns’ bolted anchor, using a directional made from a cluster of cams.
content.location:
It is just left of

Coronabushes

.

climbs.name: SuckyWahkyMuckyFucky
climbs.fa: Ross Swanson, Mike Endicott, George Bracksieck

content.description:
P1. Climb up cracks and small ledges to a roof, and go left under the roof and following slanting cracks in dihedrals & under roofs to the left. Watch for loose blocks. At about 30 meters, set a belay at a small ledge at edge of rock face just above blocky corners.

P2. Step up, and traverse right for 7 meters then up to huge ledge. With double ropes, you may combine this with P1, otherwise the rope drag would be great.

P3. Walk right on a ledge until below a big, left-facing corner. Sprint up broken cracks using your #4.5 at a large gap. Follow cracks up and left around corners.
content.location: After crossing bridge, walk upstream 50 feet, turn left, and head to a clearing. At a rock face, scramble around on the left side in a loop on 3rd Class terrain to gain the upper ledge.

climbs.name: Man's Best Friend
climbs.fa: Todd Bol and Eric Van Doren

content.description: This has a scary start, so I traversed in from left then had my belayer remove the pro. Follow bolts up to ledge then around right side of arete then back left to clip a fixed pin under a lip on the face. Proceed up and slightly left on good holds. If you stay on arete at upper section, then it has 5.10 climbing.
content.protection: About 8 bolts with 2 bolt anchor. If you traverse in from left, then add couple pieces of pro.
content.location: After crossing a bridge, walk upstream 200 feet to clearing under a face.

content.description:
Climb the dirty, bushy, right-facing dihedral, and continue up discontinuous shallow cracks. Under the overhang, traverse right to the ledge, to the two-bolt anchor atop “

Man's Best Friend

.” Most of the holds are covered with lichen and moss. Some blocks seem loose. Good pro must be cleverly placed when the rare opportunity presents. This is true adventure climbing. That said, climbing movement is good in the upper half.
content.protection: Full rack, from small wires to doubles of gold and blue Camalots.
content.location:
About five feet left of “

Unknown Right Crack

.”

content.description:
Around the corner to the right of

Man’s Best Friend

is a dirty, right-facing dihedral. Using the

MBF

anchor on 6/27/20, I toproped the lower part of the dihedral, moving left and up the clean, slightly overhanging face that forms the left wall (crux), eventually reaching the

MBF

arete. To lead this, a bolt or two should first be placed on the slightly overhanging face.
content.protection: A standard rack plus yet-to-be-placed bolt(s).

pathTokens: Middle Fork of St. Vrain Canyon
